content.webTitle: Kit Symons intends to make caretaker role permanent at Fulham

fields.headline: Kit Symons intends to make caretaker role permanent at Fulham
fields.bodyText: Kit Symons has announced his intention to make the Fulham manager’s job his own after being installed on a caretaker basis by the club’s owner, Shahid Khan, after the dismissal of Felix Magath. The club’s under-21s coach will get his first chance to impress when Fulham entertain Blackburn Rovers at Craven Cottage on Saturday and the former Wales international has described his promotion as “a great opportunity for me at a club I know very well and love very much”. Following last season’s relegation from the Premier League the Cottagers are anchored to the bottom of the Championship with one point from a possible 21 after a nightmarish start to the season. But despite their current predicament, Symons is confident he can turn things round. “It’s been a difficult time for the football club,” he says. “I think everybody wants and craves stability at Fulham and I aim to bring that back.” The former Celtic manager Neil Lennon told the BBC on Friday night that he was interested in the Fulham post and the vacancy at Cardiff City. “They are two excellent clubs,” he told Radio 5 Live. “Would I be interested in managing either of them? Of course I would.” Khan has pledged to undertake “an exhaustive, thorough and deliberate” search for a new manager but has confirmed Symons will have an opportunity to stake a claim. “I plan to summon a number of qualified advisers for input, some within or close to the Fulham family and others who will bring a perspective from outside the club,” “As Kit Symons takes the reins as our caretaker manager, I will personally lead the search for our next first-team manager,” said Khan, writing in his programme notes for Saturday’s game. “To address the obvious question as to whether Kit will be in consideration, the answer is yes. But this will be an exhaustive, thorough and deliberate process. No decisions will be made for the sake of deadlines or convenience. “I plan to summon a number of qualified advisors for input, some within or close to the Fulham family and others who will bring a perspective from outside the club. In the end the decision will be mine, but the choice will be made with the benefit of excellent and highly respected counsel.” Symons, having previously performed caretaker duties at Crystal Palace and Colchester, feels he has the necessary experience to succeed Magath, having won two promotions for Fulham as a player before working in their scouting network and coaching various youth teams. “No one understands the fabric of this football club better than me,” he said. “It’s a big job but I’m really excited and very confident that we can start moving up the table very, very soon.” Invited to offer his opinion on Magath’s training methods, which are reported to have prompted no end of disquiet among his former players, Symons was diplomacy itself. “I’ve not really seen too much of what’s been going on during the week, so it’s not really for me to comment on,” he said. Subsequent remarks about results being “a by-product of the work you do and the environment you create” may have told a different story, even if Symons was describing his own methods. “I’ve got full confidence in the way I coach and the way I train and the way I manage and these players are going to love it,” he enthused. “I think doing the basics well is key. I do an attacking day, a defensive day, a transition day and if we’ve got time, we’ll work on the set pieces. Other than those four things, I don’t think there’s too much in a game of football you need to worry about.” With no set time frame in which to stake his claim for the job full-time, Symons has already been in contact with Bryan Ruiz, the Costa Rica midfielder who is one of very few fit senior players not to have been given a game by Magath at some point this season. “I spoke to him last night,” said Symons. “He’s very upbeat and confident.” He isn’t the only one. “I’ve been given an opportunity and it’s one I intend to take with both hands,” the caretaker added. Online polls suggest put-upon Fulham fans are already firmly behind Symons, who they would like to see in charge of their floundering club.
